title-group.article-title: Combination of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy and Hyalomatrix Application for Soft Tissue Defect of the Great Toe

author-notes.corresp: Yusuf Kenan Coban, Inonu University, Medical Faculty, Plastic Surgery Department, Malatya 44280, Turkey Email: ykenanc@yahoo.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Wound Healing and Tissue Repair in China

abstract.p: Soft tissue defect of the hallux can be particularly difficult to manage because of the absence of local muscle tissue for coverage. The author presents his experience of a combination therapy for severe posttraumatic soft tissue defect of the hallux in a young patient.

body.p: Loss of the hallux can lead to significant gait problems. Soft tissue defect of the hallux can be particularly difficult to manage because of the absence of local muscle tissue for coverage. To avoid great toe loss in challenging defects, local or remote flap transfers as well as other tools of wound therapy may be combined for salvage. Here, a combination therapy for severe posttraumatic soft tissue defect of the hallux in a young patient is presented.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: An 18-year-old male presented with exposed proximal phalanx defect of his right great toe. His past medical history revealed that he had debridement and cross-leg flap operations that had failed to cover the defect. At admission, routine evaluations (ie, negative wound swab culture and no sign of systemic infection) revealed no local infection sign. Three sessions of negative wound therapy (NPWT; continuous pressure of −125 mm Hg) were first applied to the wound (Figure 1A and B). Some improvement with decreased wound size and edema was seen following this therapy. Then, the resultant defect was further treated with application of hyalomatrix PA (Fidia Advanced Biopolymers, Abano Terme, Italy), topically (Figure 2). Twenty-one days later, there was near complete healing of the defect at control examination (Figure 3).

caption.p: Wound after (A) NPWT treatment and (B) hyalomatrix application to the wound
Three months later, a near complete healing of the wound is seen

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The choice for wound coverage is determined by the size of the defect, the exposure of the tissues, state of the wound, location of injury, and length of vascular pedicle required. The gold standard reconstruction for defects larger than 25 cm2 or those on distal third of the leg, ankle, and foot is the use of free muscle flaps or free perforator flaps.1,2 Alternative strategies can be tried to avoid amputation. In this case, flap reconstruction could not be performed because of the patient’s medical history of unsuccessful attempt of flap coverage and size of the loss of substance. Therefore, a staged reconstruction based on staged surgical debridement with debridement of the devitalized tissue, NPWT, and advanced dressing were performed. There is now sufficient evidence to show that NPWT is safe and will accelerate healing.3 NPWT can also be applied with other therapy modalities as a combination therapy in lower extremity complex wounds.4 Hyaluronic acid (HA) is one of the main extracellular matrix (ECM) components; the main role of HA in the tissue repair process consists in promoting the entry of a large number of cells into the injured area. This dermal substitute provides a 3-dimensional scaffold useful for the ordered colonization of fibroblast, endothelial cells, and the deposition of ECM components, favoring a correct and anatomic 3-dimensional reconstruction of the dermal tissue.5 In this report, I present a successful treatment with a combination of NPWT and HA application in a severe wound on the hallux. I believe that such a combination therapy may solve challenging clinical situations in selected cases.
